subject: Entrepreneurship
title: The Birth of Social Entrepreneurship
description: A quick, practical guide to The Birth of Social Entrepreneurship.

hook.text: In 1980, Bill Drayton quit his government job to back people who solve social problems like entrepreneurs.

buildup.text: He founded Ashoka and invented a new label: the social entrepreneurâ€”someone who builds systems, not charities.

discovery.text: Drayton saw that charities treat symptoms. Entrepreneurs build self-sustaining systems that fix root causes.

twist.text: His first Ashoka fellow, a woman in India, had already vaccinated 100,000 children through village networks.

climax.text: Today Ashoka has funded 3,800 fellows in 93 countries. The phrase 'social entrepreneur' became a movement.

punchline.text: Charity gives fish. Social enterprise redesigns the pond.

quiz.question: What did Bill Drayton's organization Ashoka set out to support?
options: People who build self-sustaining systems to solve social problems
Traditional charities that distribute aid to developing nations
Government programs that fund community development projects
